user_request: A poem where the speaker addresses death as not proud, and sleep is but a short rest.
final_poem:
**Non-Pride, Brief as Sleep**

Death, thou shalt not brag

On this score: I've met thy ken
And found thee out for what thou art—
A summer snore the body makes,
A dropping of all careful thought,
The settling of a damp sheet,
No more. Consider: when thou takest
Thee to bed with any gentleman
Of forty, say, or thereabouts,
What hast thou found? A brief ceasing.
That's all. Thy pride upon thy tombstone—
But even that is only sleep
With accounts docketted beside.

And what of beauty, which thou think'st
To hold some title over me?
Why should my soul not rise refreshed
As any schoolboy from his rest,
His ink-stained sheets still smearing dreams
Of girls or tests? The body sleeps.
The spirit—though it too may flag—
Can count thy hours on one hand
And find them wanting. Not proud, Death,
Not proud at all: just the long night
Drawing its linen curtains
Across a room where nothing happens,
Where even wonder fogs its eye.

So here's to those who've woken
Mid-sentence, mid-amour, mid-thought—
Half-asleep, still driving. Sleep
Is but the body's courtesy.
The soul has other schedules.
And I have mine.
